text:
My father had worked for a
multinational all his life.

But right at the end when
he was about to retire,

that company which was a
shipping company closed down.

So he started this
business, which

was he imported three
Swiss embroidery machines

and set up a small
embroidery unit.

And he was simply
making the same quality

of embroidered fabric which
was fairly inexpensive which

sold in the market, lots of
other people were making it.

So my brother just
graduated college in the US

actually, and was trying to work
out various things about what
should he do, look for a job.

The two of us said, we have the
same machines as the Swiss do,

look at what we make, look
at what the Swiss make.

And we're going to
make Swiss quality.

And then everybody just
said, you guys have lost it.

It's not possible to
make quality in Pakistan.

Because at that time, 1983, '84,
all quality fabrics definitely

and all quality products were
foreign smuggled or imported.

And anything made
in Pakistan was

supposed to be inexpensive
and poor quality.

Pakistan made
pretty good cotton.

But the dyeing, so
dyeing was poor quality.

The weaving, nobody cared
about quality actually,

and I think that's
where the problem was.

We wanted to do a pure
cotton enterprise.

That was our whole
dream, was pure cotton.

I keep telling everyone
we were young and crazy.

I can see no other
reason for such a belief
that we can do it.

So we put together our
own money and made a plan.
You had to tweak everything.
We found a little dyeing unit.

I still remember when
we were talking to him

and he said, absolutely,
I'll do this for you.

But remember that the sample
I make for you will never

match your sample and
my sample will never

match the lot that-- when you do
a larger lot like 1,000 yards,
it'll never match the sample.

And one lot will never
match the other lot.
So there's no standardization?
There's no standardization.

And of course, he
said, and everybody,

said how do you create
colors which don't bleed?

We ended up paying more
for dyeing the fabric then
you could by a yard of fabric.

So our commitment was
absolutely to quality.

The first lots were stamped,
were made in Pakistan
in every yard.

But luckily or unluckily, some
of the stamps were crooked
and the color ran.

All that experience
taught us that if there's

a stamp or if there's
some writing on it,

people can copy it
and that can be wrong.

So forever after that, the
fabric that we make and we sell

has no stamp on it so that
people will check every yarn

and buy it if they think
it is the right quality.
